trait.name: Multiattack
entries: The digger can make two attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 4d12 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage and ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Swallow {@recharge 5}
entries: The digger can attempt to swallow a creature that is in range of his bite attack. The creature can make a Dexterity Saving Throw {@dc 16}. In a failiure, the creature is considered {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained} and takes ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) piercing damage and ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage.

bonus.name: Opportunistic Assault
entries: As a bonus action, the digger can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that is {@condition prone} and the digger can sense it and make a bite attack

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the boar moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the boar takes 10 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the boar moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the boar takes 10 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellasting
headerEntries: The ranger's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 17}. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Distant Strike
entries: On his turn the ranger can teleport up to 10 feet before one of his attack to an unoccupied space he can see. He can use this once in each of his turns.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ranger has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The ranger's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Multiattack
entries: The ranger makes two heavy crossbow attacks.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow - Red Bolts
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage. All creatures in line from the attack have to make a Dexterity Saving Thrown {@dc 17} to avoid the piercing red bolts.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow -  White Bolts
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h} 20 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) force damage. This attack ignores cover and strong wind.

bonus.name: Fleet of Foot
entries: Einhar can use the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Doguito makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d12 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage. If the target is {@condition prone} an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage is dealt to the target.

reaction.name: Bloody Rampage
entries: When Doguito takes damage, it makes one attack with its claws against a random creature within its reach, other than its master.
I suspect gray renders owe their origin to the neogi, since they are often in their company. Those that appear in the wilderness are likely castaways from frustrated neogi masters.

entries.name: Gray Render
entries: A curious impulse drives the gray render. Despite its hulking form and terrible appetite, it wants most of all to bond with an intelligent creature and, once bonded, give its life to protect that creature. Great strength and a savage nature enable gray renders to be fierce guardians, but they lack even a shred of cunning.

entries.name: A Spreading Plague
entries: Gray renders reproduce by forming nodules on their bodies that, upon reaching maturity, break off to begin life as young gray renders. These monstrosities feel no obligation to their young, and they have no inclination to gather with others of their kind.

entries.name: Chaotic Allies
entries: As a side effect of its breeding, each gray render has an overpowering need to bond with an intelligent creature. When it encounters a suitable master, the render sings to it‚Äîa weird, warbling cry accompanied by scratching at the earth and a show of deference. Once it forms the bond, the render serves its master in all things.

Although this bond can be a great benefit, renders are inherently chaotic. In a battle, a render fights with all the savagery it can muster and never willingly harms its master, but outside battle, a gray render might present considerable difficulty for its master's associates. It might follow its master even after being told to stay put, destroy its master's house, burrow holes in the side of a ship, kill horses, attack when it feels jealous, and more. A gray render might be a boon companion, but it is always an unpredictable one.
The Gray Render Quirks table presents possible quirks for gray renders that can be generated randomly or selected as desired.

entries.caption: Grey Render Quirk
rows: Hates horses and other mounts or pets
Roars loudly when its bonded creature is touched by another creature
Brings offerings of meat to its bonded creature
Attacks carts and wagons as if they were terrible monsters
Chases birds, leaping into the air to catch them, heedless of the destruction it causes

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The reverser has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The reverser makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 5 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 5}) piercing damage plus 6 ({@damage 1d12}) force damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) force damage.

reaction.name: Reversal
entries: When a creature the reverser can see within 30 feet of it regains hit points, the reverser reduces the number of hit points regained to 0, and the reverser deals 13 ({@damage 3d8}) force damage to the creature.

A reverser is a terrible foe in melee, laying into other creatures with teeth and claw. But the chaos it imposes is more fearful by far, as its enemies' healing magic are unraveled and turned against them.

Brought to life by mages in the flying city of Aeor during the Age of Arcanum, Aeorian hunters were created to take on angels, demons, devils, fey, and the gods themselves. When Aeor crashed into Eiselcross, many of these magically mutated monstrosities survived, and they now stalk Aeor's ruins and the islands' icy wastes.

entries.name: Created by Experimentation
entries: Aeorian hunters were created through arcane experimentation on beasts and humanoids‚Äîboth captives and volunteers. These experiments resulted in monstrosities with brightly colored flesh and the power to resist and destroy Aeor's enemies. It is theorized that the mages of Aeor must have possessed some means of controlling their monstrous soldiers, but no such device has yet been found in the wastes of Eiselcross. Draconic was the language used by these mages to train and bind the Aeorian hunters, and the hunters retain an understanding of this language even though they can't speak it.

entries.name: Madness through Immortality
entries: Aeorian hunters do not age. As such, the lust for violence their creators instilled in their minds has grown ravenous after centuries without war. Most immediately attack any creature they see.

entries.name: Never Harm Another Hunter
entries: Though they crave violence, Aeorian hunters have never been seen attacking each other. Most scholars believe that Aeor's mages must have enchanted this behavior into them, given the cost in gold and magic required to create each hunter. Some adventurers in Eiselcross boast about sneaking past Aeorian hunters using disguises or illusions to mimic a hunter's form, but these are most likely tall tales.

entries.name: Ageless Memories
entries: Each Aeorian hunter has perfect recall of every experience since the moment of its creation. Their limited intellects and desire for violence prevent them from effectively communicating, but each hunter holds a wealth of knowledge‚Äîoften including the location of rare Aeorian relics‚Äîinside its mind.

entries.name: Perfect Soldiers
entries: Aeorian hunters don't require food or drink.
